property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The dynamic dataflow (DDF) domain is a superset of the synchronous dataflow(SDF) and Boolean dataflow(BDF) domains. In the SDF domain, an actor consumes and produces a fixed number of tokens per firing. This static information makes possible compile-time scheduling. In the DDF domain, there are few constraints on the production and consumption behavior of actors, and the schedulers make no attempt to construct a compile-time schedule. Instead, each actor has a set of firing rules (patterns) and can be fired if one of them is satisfied, i.e., one particular firing pattern forms a prefix of sequences of unconsumed tokens at input ports. The canonical actors in the DDF domain include Select and Switch, which consume or produce tokens on different channels based on the token received from the control port. (In practice, use DDFSelect and DDFBooleanSelect in the DDF-specific library instead of Select and BooleanSelect in the regular FlowControl library; however, Switch and BooleanSwitch in the regular FlowControl library can be used in DDF domain.)

The dynamic scheduler implemented in this director fires all enabled and non-deferrable actors once in a basic iteration. A deferrable actor is one that will not help one of the downstream actors become enabled because that downstream actor either already has enough tokens on the channel connecting those two actors or is waiting for tokens on another channel. If no actor fires so far, which means there is no enabled and non-deferrable actor, then among all enabled and deferrable actors, this director fires those which have the smallest maximum number of tokens on their output channels which satisfy the demand of destination actors. If still no actor fires, then there is no enabled actor. A user can treat several such basic iterations as a single iteration by adding a parameter with name requiredFiringsPerIteration to an actor (which is often a sink actor or an actor directly connected to output port of the composite actor) and specifying the number of times this actor must be fired in a single iteration. If the value of the parameter runUntilDeadlockInOneIteration is a BooleanToken with value true, one single iteration consists of repeating the basic iteration until deadlock is reached (thus overriding the previous definition of one iteration), which is the status of the model where all active actors under the control of this director are unable to fire because their firing rules are not satisfied. However, they may be able to fire again during next iteration when tokens are transferred in from an outside domain. Note runUntilDeadlockInOneIteration can be set to true only when this director is not on the top level.

The algorithm implementing one basic iteration goes like this: 

            E = set of enabled actors
            D = set of deferrable enabled actors
One basic(default) iteration consists of: 
            if (E\D != empty set) {
            fire (E\D)
            } else if (D != empty set) {
            fire minimax(D)
            } else {
            declare deadlock
            }
The function "minimax(D)" returns a subset of D with the smallest maximum number of tokens on their output channels which satisfy the demand of destination actors.

Note that any SDF model can be run with a DDF Director. However, the notion of iteration is different. One could try to imitate the SDF iteration in the DDF domain by controlling the number of firings in one iteration for some actors, such as requiring a plotter to plot a fixed number of points in each iteration.

In the DDF domain, the firing rule of any actor is specified by the token consumption rates of its input ports. A general DDF actor could change the consumption rates of its input ports after each firing of this actor. For multiports, an array token could be used to specify different rates for different channels connected to the same multiport. Note that in SDF, all channels connected to the same multiport have the same rate.

Based on DDFSimpleSched in Ptolemy Classic, by Edward Lee. See E. A. Lee et al., "The Almagest," documentation for Ptolemy Classic, Vol. 1, Chapter 7, 1997.

property.name: prop:maximumReceiverCapacity
property.configure: A Parameter representing the maximum capacity of each receiver controlled by this director. This is an integer that defaults to 0, which means the queue in each receiver is unbounded. To specify bounded queues, set this to a positive integer.

property.name: prop:iterations
property.configure: Specify the number of times a workflow is iterated. By default, this parameter is set to "0". Note that "0" does not mean "no iterations." Rather, "0" means that the workflow will iterate forever. Values greater than zero specify the actual number of times the director should execute the entire workflow.

property.name: prop:runUntilDeadlockInOneIteration
property.configure: A parameter indicating whether one iteration consists of repeated basic iterations until deadlock. If this parameter is true, the model will be executed until deadlock in one iteration. The default value is a BooleanToken with the value false. It cannot be set to true if this director is at the top level.

property.name: author
property.configure: M. Aradi and BME NTI fusion group

property.name: author
property.configure: M. Aradi and BME NTI fusion group

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
runafluid_switch: ABCD

A 1: Dreicer generation rate turned ON | 0: OFF

B 1: Dreicer rate with Connor (63) | 0: see C

C 1: Dreicer rate with Connor (67) | 0: Dreicer rate with Connor (66)

D 1: Avalanche generation rate turned ON | 0: OFF

property.name: description
property.value:
runafluid_switch: ABCD

A 1: Dreicer generation rate turned ON | 0: OFF

B 1: Dreicer rate with Connor (63) | 0: see C

C 1: Dreicer rate with Connor (67) | 0: Dreicer rate with Connor (66)

D 1: Avalanche generation rate turned ON | 0: OFF

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure: Use the Annotation attribute to annotate a workflow. Double-click the attribute to customize the content, font size, color, and basic formatting (bold and italics).

property.name: prop:fontFamily
property.configure: The font face. Select a font from the drop-down menu. The default is "SansSerif".

property.name: prop:italic
property.configure: Select to indicate that the type should be italics. By default, type will not be italicized.

property.name: prop:bold
property.configure: Select to indicate that the type should be bold. By default, type will not be bold.

property.name: prop:textColor
property.configure: The font color. Specify a string representing an array of four elements: red, green, blue, and alpha, where alpha is transparency. The default is an opaque black, {0.0, 0.0, 0.0, 1.0}

property.name: prop:textSize
property.configure: The font size. Select an integer from the drop-down menu or specify a new size by typing it directly into the value field. The default is 14.

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
electric_field_switch: ABCD (Do not write starting 0s!)

A 0: non-increasing field 1: increasing field

B 0: linear 1: logarithmic

C 0: absolute field 1: critical field

D 0: related to Dreicer field 1: related to critical field

property.name: description
property.value:
electric_field_switch: ABCD (Do not write starting 0s!)

A 0: non-increasing field 1: increasing field

B 0: linear 1: logarithmic

C 0: absolute field 1: critical field

D 0: related to Dreicer field 1: related to critical field

property.name: author
property.configure: Neil Smyth, Edward A. Lee, Xiaojun Liu

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
Parameter extends Variable with additional support for string-valued variables that makes these friendlier at the user interface level. In particular, this class supports an annotation that specifies choices for values. A user interface can use this to present a choice dialog that offers the specified values. This is typically used when a particular set of choices make sense. The values can be any expression, or if used in conjunction with string mode, any string.

By default, an instance of Parameter, unlike Variable, is persistent.

By convention, an instance of NamedObj has a set of attributes, some of which are visible to users and some of which are not. When a user interface presents these attributes for editing, it presents only those that are visible. By default, an instance of Parameter is visible, as indicated by the fact that it returns FULL in its getVisibility() method. This can be overridden by calling setVisibility().

property.name: description
property.value:

By default, an instance of Parameter, unlike Variable, is persistent.

property.name: author
property.value: Neil Smyth, Edward A. Lee, Xiaojun Liu

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
StringParameter specifies a persistent string.

Change the name of the StringParameter to better identify the specified value (right-click the parameter and select "Customize Name" from the menu). Other actors may refer to the StringParameter using the $NAME syntax (e.g. $Parameter).

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
StringParameter specifies a persistent string.

Change the name of the StringParameter to better identify the specified value (right-click the parameter and select "Customize Name" from the menu). Other actors may refer to the StringParameter using the $NAME syntax (e.g. $Parameter).

property.name: text
property.value:
runaway_indicator actor in runaway-indicator-wrapper composite actor for RUNAFLUID are located in the main folder of the RUNIN project.
Check out files from RUNINrepository: https://gforge.efda-itm.eu/svn/runin

property.name: userLevelDocumentation

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
A Composite actor is an aggregation of actors. It may have a local director that is responsible for executing the contained actors. A Composite actor with a local director is called an opaque actor. Composite actors do not require a local director. Composite actors with no local director "inherit" the director from the containing workflow and are called non-opaque.

To create a composite actor, drag and drop the Composite actor onto the Workflow canvas. Right-click the actor and select Open Actor from the drop-down menu. A new Kepler application window will open for designing the composite.

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure: A parameter specifying default title to associate with a model and with components in the model. By default, this attribute uses the model name and component names as the title.

property.name: prop:height
property.configure: Parameter specifying the height of the editing box. This is an int that defaults to 20.

property.name: prop:showTitleInHTML
property.configure: If set to true, then the title given by this parameter will be shown in the HTML prior to the image of the model (as well as in the image of the model, if it is visible when the export to web occurs). This is a boolean that defaults to true.

property.name: prop:include
property.configure: Specification of whether to provide the title for Attributes, Entities, or both. This is either "Entities" (the default), "Attributes", "All", or "None".

property.name: prop:width
property.configure: Parameter specifying the width of the editing box. This is an int that defaults to 60.

property.name: prop:displayText
property.configure: Parameter giving the text to display in the Ptolemy model. This defaults to "Content for Export to Web".

property.name: prop:instancesOf
property.configure: If non-empty (the default), specifies a class name. Only entities or attributes (depending on include) implementing the specified class will be assigned the title defined by this DefaultTitle parameter.

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure: A parameter specifying default title to associate with a model and with components in the model. By default, this attribute uses the model name and component names as the title.

property.name: prop:include
property.configure: Specification of whether to provide the title for Attributes, Entities, or both. This is either "Entities" (the default), "Attributes", "All", or "None".

property.configure: If set to true, then the title given by this parameter will be shown in the HTML prior to the image of the model (as well as in the image of the model, if it is visible when the export to web occurs). This is a boolean that defaults to true.

property.configure: Parameter giving the text to display in the Ptolemy model. This defaults to "Content for Export to Web".

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The ualinit actor reads from the database a shot with the specified run number and copies it to a working run number. You can generate any cpo output by using the "configure ports" option. You can specified the occurrence number of the CPOs read in the database by giving the name of the output with "/occurence_number" for instance equilibrium/1 means equilibrium cpo with occurrence 1. The CPO is copied to the working run number with the same occurrence number.

The output is a record which contains: idx, the reference of an entry of the database, shot, the shot number, run, the run number, cpo, the name of the cpo, occurrence,the number of the occurrencei, machine, the name of the machine, user, the user name, version, the UAL version.

property.name: port:user
property.configure: input the user name. It is optional. The default is the name of the current user.

property.name: port:machine
property.configure: input the machine name. It is optional. The default is the name of the current machine name.

property.name: port:run
property.configure: input the run number which will be duplicated to the work run number

property.name: prop:enableISE
property.configure: You must not modify this parameter

property.name: prop:euitmCreate
property.configure: If your shot is not defined in the database, you can create it by activing this option

property.name: prop:enableMemCache
property.configure: all cpo are stored in memory. The ualcollector, ualslicecollector and ualclose actors enable to flush the cpo from the memory to the disk.

property.name: expression
author
property.configure: Xiaojun Liu, Edward A. Lee, Steve Neuendorffer

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The Expression actor evaluates a specified expression (e.g., an addition or multiplication operation), which may reference the values of user-specified input ports, the current time, or the actor's iteration count. The actor outputs the value of the evaluated expression.

Expressions are specified in the Ptolemy expression language via the expression parameter. For more information about the expression language, see http://ptolemy.eecs.berkeley.edu/papers/05/ptIIdesign1-intro/ptIIdesign1-intro.pdf.

By default, the expression parameter is empty, and attempting to execute the actor without first specifying an expression generates an error. Expressions can refer to the values of inputs by the port name; to the current time by the identifier "time"; and to the current iteration count by the identifier "iteration."

Input ports are created by the user and correspond to variables used in the specified expression. Currently, the Expression actor does not support input multiports. The actor requires all of its inputs to be present. If inputs are not all present, then the actor will generate an error.

Note: the Expression actor can be used instead of many of the arithmetic actors, such as AddSubtract, MultiplyDivide, and TrigFunction. However, those actors will be usually be more efficient, and sometimes more convenient to use.

property.name: port:output
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts the value of the evaluated expression. The actor automatically determines the type based on the type of the input.

property.name: prop:expression
property.configure: An expression to evaluate. Expressions are specified in the Ptolemy expression language. For more information about the expression language, see http://ptolemy.eecs.berkeley.edu/papers/05/ptIIdesign1-intro/ptIIdesign1-intro.pdf. By default, the parameter is empty, and attempting to execute the actor without first specifying an expression generates an error. Expressions can refer to the values of inputs by the port name; to the current time by the identifier "time"; and to the current iteration count by the identifier "iteration."

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The Constant actor outputs a constant, which is specified by the value parameter. By default, the actor outputs the integer 1.

The actor can be used to output other types of values, e.g., a string (such as "Hello") or a double (such as 1.2). The actor' s output type matches the type of the specified value.

NOTE: If using a PN Director, the 'firingCountLimit' parameter is often set to a finite integer (e.g. '1') so that the workflow will terminate.

property.name: port:output
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts the specified constant. By default, the output is 1.

property.name: port:trigger
property.configure: A multiport that has no declared type (in other words, the port can accept any data type: double, int, array, etc.) If the port is connected, the actor will not fire until the trigger port receives an input token. Connecting the port is optional, but useful when scheduling the actor to perform at a certain time.

property.name: prop:firingCountLimit
property.configure: The limit on the number of times the actor will fire. The default value is 'NONE', meaning there is no limit on the number of time the constant will be provided to the output port. Any integer can be provided as a value for this parameter.

property.name: prop:value
property.configure: The value produced by the Constant actor. By default, the value is the integer token 1. The value can be set to another type, e.g., a string (such as "Hello") or a double (such as 1.2). The output type matches the type of the value specified here.

property.name: prop:value

By default, the expression parameter is empty, and attempting to execute the actor without first specifying an expression generates an error. Expressions can refer to the values of inputs by the port name; to the current time by the identifier "time"; and to the current iteration count by the identifier "iteration."

Input ports are created by the user and correspond to variables used in the specified expression. Currently, the Expression actor does not support input multiports. The actor requires all of its inputs to be present. If inputs are not all present, then the actor will generate an error.

Note: the Expression actor can be used instead of many of the arithmetic actors, such as AddSubtract, MultiplyDivide, and TrigFunction. However, those actors will be usually be more efficient, and sometimes more convenient to use.

property.name: port:output
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts the value of the evaluated expression. The actor automatically determines the type based on the type of the input.

property.name: prop:expression
property.configure: An expression to evaluate. Expressions are specified in the Ptolemy expression language. For more information about the expression language, see http://ptolemy.eecs.berkeley.edu/papers/05/ptIIdesign1-intro/ptIIdesign1-intro.pdf. By default, the parameter is empty, and attempting to execute the actor without first specifying an expression generates an error. Expressions can refer to the values of inputs by the port name; to the current time by the identifier "time"; and to the current iteration count by the identifier "iteration."

property.name: author
property.configure: Xiaojun Liu, Edward A. Lee, Steve Neuendorffer

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The Expression actor evaluates a specified expression (e.g., an addition or multiplication operation), which may reference the values of user-specified input ports, the current time, or the actor's iteration count. The actor outputs the value of the evaluated expression.

Expressions are specified in the Ptolemy expression language via the expression parameter. For more information about the expression language, see http://ptolemy.eecs.berkeley.edu/papers/05/ptIIdesign1-intro/ptIIdesign1-intro.pdf.

By default, the expression parameter is empty, and attempting to execute the actor without first specifying an expression generates an error. Expressions can refer to the values of inputs by the port name; to the current time by the identifier "time"; and to the current iteration count by the identifier "iteration."

Input ports are created by the user and correspond to variables used in the specified expression. Currently, the Expression actor does not support input multiports. The actor requires all of its inputs to be present. If inputs are not all present, then the actor will generate an error.

Note: the Expression actor can be used instead of many of the arithmetic actors, such as AddSubtract, MultiplyDivide, and TrigFunction. However, those actors will be usually be more efficient, and sometimes more convenient to use.

property.name: port:output
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts the value of the evaluated expression. The actor automatically determines the type based on the type of the input.

property.name: prop:expression
property.configure: An expression to evaluate. Expressions are specified in the Ptolemy expression language. For more information about the expression language, see http://ptolemy.eecs.berkeley.edu/papers/05/ptIIdesign1-intro/ptIIdesign1-intro.pdf. By default, the parameter is empty, and attempting to execute the actor without first specifying an expression generates an error. Expressions can refer to the values of inputs by the port name; to the current time by the identifier "time"; and to the current iteration count by the identifier "iteration."

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
A Composite actor is an aggregation of actors. It may have a local director that is responsible for executing the contained actors. A Composite actor with a local director is called an opaque actor. Composite actors do not require a local director. Composite actors with no local director "inherit" the director from the containing workflow and are called non-opaque.

To create a composite actor, drag and drop the Composite actor onto the Workflow canvas. Right-click the actor and select Open Actor from the drop-down menu. A new Kepler application window will open for designing the composite.

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure: Use the Annotation attribute to annotate a workflow. Double-click the attribute to customize the content, font size, color, and basic formatting (bold and italics).

property.name: prop:fontFamily
property.configure: The font face. Select a font from the drop-down menu. The default is "SansSerif".

property.name: prop:italic
property.configure: Select to indicate that the type should be italics. By default, type will not be italicized.

property.name: prop:bold
property.configure: Select to indicate that the type should be bold. By default, type will not be bold.

property.name: prop:textColor
property.configure: The font color. Specify a string representing an array of four elements: red, green, blue, and alpha, where alpha is transparency. The default is an opaque black, {0.0, 0.0, 0.0, 1.0}

property.name: prop:textSize
property.configure: The font size. Select an integer from the drop-down menu or specify a new size by typing it directly into the value field. The default is 14.

property.name: author
property.configure: Xiaojun Liu, Edward A. Lee, Steve Neuendorffer

property.name: prop:verbMode
property.configure: print also fields which do not contain stored data

property.name: prop:treeMode
property.configure: print fields hierarchy instead of full path

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure: Displays all the fields that are not empty in the input CPO

property.name: Code parameters
property.value:
<?xml version="1.0"?>
<?xml-stylesheet type="text/xsl" href="./source_dummy.xsl" charset="ISO-8859-1"?>
<parameters>
<currents>
<JNITOT> 1.E5 </JNITOT> <!-- Total noninductive current [A] --> <RCURR> 0.5 </RCURR> <!-- Position of the current profile maximum [m] --> <FWCURR> 0.2 </FWCURR> <!-- Full width at the halth maximum of current profile [m] -->
</currents>
<electrons>
<heating_el> <WTOT_el> 1.E6 </WTOT_el> <!-- Total heating power [W] --> <RHEAT_el> 0.5 </RHEAT_el> <!-- Position of the heating profile maximum [m] --> <FWHEAT_el> 0.2 </FWHEAT_el> <!-- Full width at the halth maximum of heating profile [m] --> </heating_el>
<particles_el> <STOT_el> 1.E21 </STOT_el> <!-- Injection rate [s^-1] --> <RPART_el> 0.0 </RPART_el> <!-- Position of the source profile maximum [m] --> <FWPART_el> 1.0 </FWPART_el> <!-- Full width at the halth maximum of source profile [m] --> </particles_el>
</electrons>
<ions> <composition> <AMN> 2.0 </AMN> <!-- Total heating power [W] --> <ZN> 1.0 </ZN> <!-- Position of the heating profile maximum [m] --> <ZION> 1.0 </ZION> <!-- fraction of power going in different components [-] --> </composition>
<heating> <WTOT> 1.E6 </WTOT> <!-- Total heating power [W] --> <RHEAT> 0.0 </RHEAT> <!-- Position of the heating profile maximum [m] --> <FWHEAT> 0.5 </FWHEAT> <!-- Full width at the halth maximum of heating profile [m] --> </heating>
<particles> <STOT> 1.E21 </STOT> <!-- Injection rate [s^-1] --> <RPART> 0.0 </RPART> <!-- Position of the source profile maximum [m] --> <FWPART> 1.0 </FWPART> <!-- Full width at the halth maximum of source profile [m] --> </particles>
<momentum> <UTOT> 0.E0 </UTOT> <!-- Total momentum [kg*m^2*s^-1] --> <RMOM> 0.0 </RMOM> <!-- Position of the momentum profile maximum [m] --> <FWMOM> 1.0 </FWMOM> <!-- Full width at the halth maximum of momentum profile [m] --> </momentum>
</ions>
</parameters>

property.name: Default Code parameters
property.value:
<?xml version="1.0"?>
<?xml-stylesheet type="text/xsl" href="./source_dummy.xsl" charset="ISO-8859-1"?>
<parameters>
<currents>
<JNITOT> 1.E5 </JNITOT> <!-- Total noninductive current [A] --> <RCURR> 0.5 </RCURR> <!-- Position of the current profile maximum [m] --> <FWCURR> 0.2 </FWCURR> <!-- Full width at the halth maximum of current profile [m] -->
</currents>
<electrons>
<heating_el> <WTOT_el> 1.E6 </WTOT_el> <!-- Total heating power [W] --> <RHEAT_el> 0.5 </RHEAT_el> <!-- Position of the heating profile maximum [m] --> <FWHEAT_el> 0.2 </FWHEAT_el> <!-- Full width at the halth maximum of heating profile [m] --> </heating_el>
<particles_el> <STOT_el> 1.E21 </STOT_el> <!-- Injection rate [s^-1] --> <RPART_el> 0.0 </RPART_el> <!-- Position of the source profile maximum [m] --> <FWPART_el> 1.0 </FWPART_el> <!-- Full width at the halth maximum of source profile [m] --> </particles_el>
</electrons>
<ions> <composition> <AMN> 2.0 </AMN> <!-- Total heating power [W] --> <ZN> 1.0 </ZN> <!-- Position of the heating profile maximum [m] --> <ZION> 1.0 </ZION> <!-- fraction of power going in different components [-] --> </composition>
<heating> <WTOT> 1.E6 </WTOT> <!-- Total heating power [W] --> <RHEAT> 0.0 </RHEAT> <!-- Position of the heating profile maximum [m] --> <FWHEAT> 0.5 </FWHEAT> <!-- Full width at the halth maximum of heating profile [m] --> </heating>
<particles> <STOT> 1.E21 </STOT> <!-- Injection rate [s^-1] --> <RPART> 0.0 </RPART> <!-- Position of the source profile maximum [m] --> <FWPART> 1.0 </FWPART> <!-- Full width at the halth maximum of source profile [m] --> </particles>
<momentum> <UTOT> 0.E0 </UTOT> <!-- Total momentum [kg*m^2*s^-1] --> <RMOM> 0.0 </RMOM> <!-- Position of the momentum profile maximum [m] --> <FWMOM> 1.0 </FWMOM> <!-- Full width at the halth maximum of momentum profile [m] --> </momentum>
</ions>
</parameters>

property.name: XSD Code parameters
property.value:
<xs:schema xmlns:xs="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <!-- document element --> <xs:element name="parameters"> <xs:annotation> <xs:documentation> GLOBAL: parameters for Gaussian sources </xs:documentation> </xs:annotation> <xs:complexType> <xs:all> <xs:element ref="currents" maxOccurs="1"/> <xs:element ref="electrons" maxOccurs="1"/> <xs:element ref="ions" maxOccurs="1"/> </xs:all> </xs:complexType> </xs:element>
<xs:simpleType name="FloatList"> <xs:list itemType="xs:float"/> </xs:simpleType>
<!-- current source parameters --> <xs:element name="currents"> <xs:annotation> <xs:documentation> BLOCK: specify currents </xs:documentation> </xs:annotation> <xs:complexType> <xs:all> <xs:element ref="JNITOT" maxOccurs="1"/> <xs:element ref="RCURR" maxOccurs="1"/> <xs:element ref="FWCURR" maxOccurs="1"/> </xs:all> </xs:complexType> </xs:element>
<xs:element name="JNITOT" type="xs:float"> <xs:annotation> <xs:documentation> Total noninductive current [A] </xs:documentation> </xs:annotation> </xs:element> <xs:element name="RCURR" type="xs:float"> <xs:annotation> <xs:documentation> Position of the current profile maximum [m] </xs:documentation> </xs:annotation> </xs:element> <xs:element name="FWCURR" type="xs:float"> <xs:annotation> <xs:documentation> Full width at the halth maximum of current profile [m] </xs:documentation> </xs:annotation> </xs:element>
<!-- electrons parameters --> <xs:element name="electrons"> <xs:annotation> <xs:documentation> BLOCK: specify electron heating </xs:documentation> </xs:annotation> <xs:complexType> <xs:all> <xs:element ref="heating_el" maxOccurs="1"/> <xs:element ref="particles_el" maxOccurs="1"/> </xs:all> </xs:complexType> </xs:element>
<xs:element name="heating_el"> <xs:annotation> <xs:documentation> BLOCK: specify heating </xs:documentation> </xs:annotation> <xs:complexType> <xs:all> <xs:element ref="WTOT_el" maxOccurs="1"/> <xs:element ref="RHEAT_el" maxOccurs="1"/> <xs:element ref="FWHEAT_el" maxOccurs="1"/> </xs:all> </xs:complexType> </xs:element> <xs:element name="WTOT_el" type="xs:float"> <xs:annotation> <xs:documentation> Total heating power [W] </xs:documentation> </xs:annotation> </xs:element> <xs:element name="RHEAT_el" type="xs:float"> <xs:annotation> <xs:documentation> Position of the heating profile maximum [m] </xs:documentation> </xs:annotation> </xs:element> <xs:element name="FWHEAT_el" type="xs:float"> <xs:annotation> <xs:documentation> Full width at the half maximum of heating profile [m] </xs:documentation> </xs:annotation> </xs:element>
<xs:element name="particles_el"> <xs:annotation> <xs:documentation> BLOCK: specify heating </xs:documentation> </xs:annotation> <xs:complexType> <xs:all> <xs:element ref="STOT_el" maxOccurs="1"/> <xs:element ref="RPART_el" maxOccurs="1"/> <xs:element ref="FWPART_el" maxOccurs="1"/> </xs:all> </xs:complexType> </xs:element> <xs:element name="STOT_el" type="xs:float"> <xs:annotation> <xs:documentation> Total electron particle source [1/s] </xs:documentation> </xs:annotation> </xs:element> <xs:element name="RPART_el" type="xs:float"> <xs:annotation> <xs:documentation> Position of the electron source profile maximum [m] </xs:documentation> </xs:annotation> </xs:element> <xs:element name="FWPART_el" type="xs:float"> <xs:annotation> <xs:documentation> Full width at the half maximum of electron source profile [m] </xs:documentation> </xs:annotation> </xs:element>
<!-- ions parameters --> <xs:element name="ions"> <xs:annotation> <xs:documentation> BLOCK: specify ion parameters </xs:documentation> </xs:annotation> <xs:complexType> <xs:all> <xs:element ref="composition" maxOccurs="1"/> <xs:element ref="heating" maxOccurs="1"/> <xs:element ref="particles" maxOccurs="1"/> <xs:element ref="momentum" maxOccurs="1"/> </xs:all> </xs:complexType> </xs:element>
<!-- composition parameters --> <xs:element name="composition"> <xs:annotation> <xs:documentation> BLOCK: specify composition </xs:documentation> </xs:annotation> <xs:complexType> <xs:all> <xs:element ref="AMN" maxOccurs="1"/> <xs:element ref="ZN" maxOccurs="1"/> <xs:element ref="ZION" maxOccurs="1"/> </xs:all> </xs:complexType> </xs:element>
<xs:element name="AMN" type="FloatList"> <xs:annotation> <xs:documentation> atomic mass; from 1 to NION </xs:documentation> </xs:annotation> </xs:element> <xs:element name="ZN" type="FloatList"> <xs:annotation> <xs:documentation> nuclear charge; from 1 to NION </xs:documentation> </xs:annotation> </xs:element> <xs:element name="ZION" type="FloatList"> <xs:annotation> <xs:documentation> charge; from 1 to NION </xs:documentation> </xs:annotation> </xs:element>
<!-- heating parameters --> <xs:element name="heating"> <xs:annotation> <xs:documentation> BLOCK: specify heating </xs:documentation> </xs:annotation> <xs:complexType> <xs:all> <xs:element ref="WTOT" maxOccurs="1"/> <xs:element ref="RHEAT" maxOccurs="1"/> <xs:element ref="FWHEAT" maxOccurs="1"/> </xs:all> </xs:complexType> </xs:element>
<xs:element name="WTOT" type="FloatList"> <xs:annotation> <xs:documentation> Total heating power [W]; from 1 to NION </xs:documentation> </xs:annotation> </xs:element> <xs:element name="RHEAT" type="FloatList"> <xs:annotation> <xs:documentation> Position of the heating profile maximum [m]; from 1 to NION </xs:documentation> </xs:annotation> </xs:element> <xs:element name="FWHEAT" type="FloatList"> <xs:annotation> <xs:documentation> Full width at the half maximum of heating profile [m]; from 1 to NION </xs:documentation> </xs:annotation> </xs:element>
<!-- particle source parameters --> <xs:element name="particles"> <xs:annotation> <xs:documentation> BLOCK: specify particles </xs:documentation> </xs:annotation> <xs:complexType> <xs:all> <xs:element ref="STOT" maxOccurs="1"/> <xs:element ref="RPART" maxOccurs="1"/> <xs:element ref="FWPART" maxOccurs="1"/> </xs:all> </xs:complexType> </xs:element>
<xs:element name="STOT" type="FloatList"> <xs:annotation> <xs:documentation> Injection rate [s^-1]; from 1 to NION </xs:documentation> </xs:annotation> </xs:element> <xs:element name="RPART" type="FloatList"> <xs:annotation> <xs:documentation> Position of the source profile maximum [m]; from 1 to NION </xs:documentation> </xs:annotation> </xs:element> <xs:element name="FWPART" type="FloatList"> <xs:annotation> <xs:documentation> Full width at the half maximum of source profile [m]; from 1 to NION </xs:documentation> </xs:annotation> </xs:element>
<!-- momentum source parameters --> <xs:element name="momentum"> <xs:annotation> <xs:documentation> BLOCK: specify momentum </xs:documentation> </xs:annotation> <xs:complexType> <xs:all> <xs:element ref="UTOT" maxOccurs="1"/> <xs:element ref="RMOM" maxOccurs="1"/> <xs:element ref="FWMOM" maxOccurs="1"/> </xs:all> </xs:complexType> </xs:element>
<xs:element name="UTOT" type="FloatList"> <xs:annotation> <xs:documentation> Total momentum [kg*m^2*s^-1]; from 1 to NION </xs:documentation> </xs:annotation> </xs:element> <xs:element name="RMOM" type="FloatList"> <xs:annotation> <xs:documentation> Position of the momentum profile maximum [m]; from 1 to NION </xs:documentation> </xs:annotation> </xs:element> <xs:element name="FWMOM" type="FloatList"> <xs:annotation> <xs:documentation> Full width at the half maximum of momentum profile [m]; from 1 to NION </xs:documentation> </xs:annotation> </xs:element>
</xs:schema>

property.name: prop:verbMode
property.configure: print also fields which do not contain stored data

property.name: prop:treeMode
property.configure: print fields hierarchy instead of full path

property.configure: Allows to change occurrence of the CPO

property.name: author
property.configure: Xiaojun Liu, Edward A. Lee, Steve Neuendorffer

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The Expression actor evaluates a specified expression (e.g., an addition or multiplication operation), which may reference the values of user-specified input ports, the current time, or the actor's iteration count. The actor outputs the value of the evaluated expression.

Expressions are specified in the Ptolemy expression language via the expression parameter. For more information about the expression language, see http://ptolemy.eecs.berkeley.edu/papers/05/ptIIdesign1-intro/ptIIdesign1-intro.pdf.

By default, the expression parameter is empty, and attempting to execute the actor without first specifying an expression generates an error. Expressions can refer to the values of inputs by the port name; to the current time by the identifier "time"; and to the current iteration count by the identifier "iteration."

Input ports are created by the user and correspond to variables used in the specified expression. Currently, the Expression actor does not support input multiports. The actor requires all of its inputs to be present. If inputs are not all present, then the actor will generate an error.

Note: the Expression actor can be used instead of many of the arithmetic actors, such as AddSubtract, MultiplyDivide, and TrigFunction. However, those actors will be usually be more efficient, and sometimes more convenient to use.

property.name: port:output
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts the value of the evaluated expression. The actor automatically determines the type based on the type of the input.

property.name: prop:expression
property.configure: An expression to evaluate. Expressions are specified in the Ptolemy expression language. For more information about the expression language, see http://ptolemy.eecs.berkeley.edu/papers/05/ptIIdesign1-intro/ptIIdesign1-intro.pdf. By default, the parameter is empty, and attempting to execute the actor without first specifying an expression generates an error. Expressions can refer to the values of inputs by the port name; to the current time by the identifier "time"; and to the current iteration count by the identifier "iteration."

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
te_switch:

AB

 A
   0: non-increasing temperature
   1: increasing temperature   
 
 B  
   0: linear
   1: logarithmic

property.name: author
property.configure: Xiaojun Liu, Edward A. Lee, Steve Neuendorffer

Expressions are specified in the Ptolemy expression language via the expression parameter. For more information about the expression language, see http://ptolemy.eecs.berkeley.edu/papers/05/ptIIdesign1-intro/ptIIdesign1-intro.pdf.

By default, the expression parameter is empty, and attempting to execute the actor without first specifying an expression generates an error. Expressions can refer to the values of inputs by the port name; to the current time by the identifier "time"; and to the current iteration count by the identifier "iteration."

Input ports are created by the user and correspond to variables used in the specified expression. Currently, the Expression actor does not support input multiports. The actor requires all of its inputs to be present. If inputs are not all present, then the actor will generate an error.

Note: the Expression actor can be used instead of many of the arithmetic actors, such as AddSubtract, MultiplyDivide, and TrigFunction. However, those actors will be usually be more efficient, and sometimes more convenient to use.

property.configure: An output port that broadcasts the value of the evaluated expression. The actor automatically determines the type based on the type of the input.

property.name: prop:expression
property.configure: An expression to evaluate. Expressions are specified in the Ptolemy expression language. For more information about the expression language, see http://ptolemy.eecs.berkeley.edu/papers/05/ptIIdesign1-intro/ptIIdesign1-intro.pdf. By default, the parameter is empty, and attempting to execute the actor without first specifying an expression generates an error. Expressions can refer to the values of inputs by the port name; to the current time by the identifier "time"; and to the current iteration count by the identifier "iteration."

property.name: author
property.configure: Xiaojun Liu, Edward A. Lee, Steve Neuendorffer

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The Expression actor evaluates a specified expression (e.g., an addition or multiplication operation), which may reference the values of user-specified input ports, the current time, or the actor's iteration count. The actor outputs the value of the evaluated expression.

Expressions are specified in the Ptolemy expression language via the expression parameter. For more information about the expression language, see http://ptolemy.eecs.berkeley.edu/papers/05/ptIIdesign1-intro/ptIIdesign1-intro.pdf.

By default, the expression parameter is empty, and attempting to execute the actor without first specifying an expression generates an error. Expressions can refer to the values of inputs by the port name; to the current time by the identifier "time"; and to the current iteration count by the identifier "iteration."

Input ports are created by the user and correspond to variables used in the specified expression. Currently, the Expression actor does not support input multiports. The actor requires all of its inputs to be present. If inputs are not all present, then the actor will generate an error.

Note: the Expression actor can be used instead of many of the arithmetic actors, such as AddSubtract, MultiplyDivide, and TrigFunction. However, those actors will be usually be more efficient, and sometimes more convenient to use.

property.name: port:output
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts the value of the evaluated expression. The actor automatically determines the type based on the type of the input.

property.name: prop:expression
property.configure: An expression to evaluate. Expressions are specified in the Ptolemy expression language. For more information about the expression language, see http://ptolemy.eecs.berkeley.edu/papers/05/ptIIdesign1-intro/ptIIdesign1-intro.pdf. By default, the parameter is empty, and attempting to execute the actor without first specifying an expression generates an error. Expressions can refer to the values of inputs by the port name; to the current time by the identifier "time"; and to the current iteration count by the identifier "iteration."
